 So you find the idea that some mysterious and shy superbeing that lives outside our universe created everything and then hid a wholeload of false information to make people think that the whole thing actually happened naturally several thousand years after he actually told a few select people what happened more beleivable than events we see everyday happening over a large scale?
 
 Even if you don't think evolution hasn't happened yet, do you deny that it could happen?
 One of the central tenents of modern biology is
 DNA encodes genes
 Genes encode protein and polypeptides 
 Proteins and polypeptides are the building blocks and machinery of organisms
 
 Alongside this you recognise that this code can be changed and DNA is inherited. Evolution is merely a result of these changes accumlumlating until the DNA of an organism is too different from its ancester many generations ago at the very least (there are other types but for the sake of the argument we will leave them out seeing as we only need one type).
 
 Unless you don't beleive in one of the points above, surely at somepoint in the future evolution would have happened. If this is true and God's creations do have the potential to change from how they were created, why is it hard to beleive that they may done so already? Or if you are feeling more philosophical why would they even be given this abilty to adapt if they weren't ment to?

So you find the idea that some mysterious and shy superbeing that lives outside our universe created everything and then hid a wholeload of false information to make people think that the whole thing actually happened naturally several thousand years after he actually told a few select people what happened more believable than events we see everyday happening over a large scale?

 You make a very unscientific claim; that the evidence is false. It is an odd position to make. I always thought that people argued that the interpretation of the evidence could be false.
 A few other points...
 God lives within and without the universe
 God is not 'shy', as He has revealed Himself to us.
 
Even if you don't think evolution hasn't happened yet, do you deny that it could happen?
 One of the central tenets of modern biology is
 DNA encodes genes
 Genes encode protein and polypeptides 
 Proteins and polypeptides are the building blocks and machinery of organisms

 The gene-centric theory is already being questioned. Further, the earth seems so suited for life, it can't have been by chance that life came about by chance. The inference is that there's an intelligence/blueprint behind it. This does not mean that the Christian God is proved by it, or God in any definition. BUT it is a form of evolutionary theory that tackles the problems of the holes in Darwin's mechanistic models.
 Michael Denton agrees with when he states that the gene-centric theory of neo-Darwinism - is insufficient to explain all aspects of biology. He states “Yet by the late 1980s it was becoming obvious to most genetic researchers, including myself, since my own main research interest in the '80s and '90s was human genetics, that the heroic effort to find the information specifying life's order in the genes had failed. There was no longer the slightest justification for believing that there exists anything in the genome remotely resembling a program capable of specifying in detail all the complex order of the phenotype... From being 'isolated directors' of a one-way game of life, genes are now considered to be interactive players in a dynamic two-way dance of almost unfathomable complexity, as described by Keller in “The Century of the Gene”
 
 Michael John Denton ”An Anti-Darwin Intellectual Journey”, in Dembski, W. A. (ed) “Uncommon Dissent: Intellectuals who Find Darwinism Unconvincing”, p172.
 
Alongside this you recognise that this code can be changed and DNA is inherited. Evolution is merely a result of these changes accumulating until the DNA of an organism is too different from its ancestor many generations ago at the very least (there are other types but for the sake of the argument we will leave them out seeing as we only need one type).

 Denton gives examples of the folds in RNA which happen consistently, and independently of genetic coding... but these rules governing the folds... “These laws of protein form are strictly equivalent to the rules that govern the way atoms are combined into molecules or subatomic particles are combined into atoms to generate the periodic table of elements...
 
 The folds present stunning evidence, perhaps the first clear evidence discovered in biology, that highly complex organic forms can be generated by natural law. With the folds, the impossible has become possible - the basic building blocks of nature are specified in abstract laws of form and are not simply a mechanical program in the genes. They are lawful, emergent, self-organising forms and not contingent 'cleverly contrived machines'. Here is a set of forms that arise directly out of the basic properties of matter, confirming the inference I had previously drawn from reading Henderson, that life might be encoded in the basic properties of matter.”
 
 Ibid, pp173-74
 
 
Unless you don't believe in one of the points above, surely at somepoint in the future evolution would have happened. If this is true and God's creations do have the potential to change from how they were created, why is it hard to believe that they may done so already? Or if you are feeling more philosophical why would they even be given this ability to adapt if they weren't ment to?

 
 I will leave that for God_is_real to answer, but note that you might be unaware of your own philosophical stance.

Tastyfish

You make a very unscientific claim; that the evidence is false. It is an odd position to make. I always thought that people argued that the interpretation of the evidence could be false.
 A few other points...
 God lives within and without the universe
 God is not 'shy', as He has revealed Himself to us.

 Ment to sound a bit silly there, kind of a response to the arguement 'come on people, slime and monkeys?' While slime and monkeys sounds silly its not hard to do the same for the otherside. 
 
 

 The gene-centric theory is already being questioned. Further, the earth seems so suited for life, it can't have been by chance that life came about by chance. The inference is that there's an intelligence/blueprint behind it. This does not mean that the Christian God is proved by it, or God in any definition. BUT it is a form of evolutionary theory that tackles the problems of the holes in Darwin's mechanistic models.
 Michael Denton agrees with when he states that the gene-centric theory of neo-Darwinism - is insufficient to explain all aspects of biology. He states "Yet by the late 1980s it was becoming obvious to most genetic researchers, including myself, since my own main research interest in the '80s and '90s was human genetics, that the heroic effort to find the information specifying life's order in the genes had failed. There was no longer the slightest justification for believing that there exists anything in the genome remotely resembling a program capable of specifying in detail all the complex order of the phenotype... From being 'isolated directors' of a one-way game of life, genes are now considered to be interactive players in a dynamic two-way dance of almost unfathomable complexity, as described by Keller in "The Century of the Gene".

 You are misinterpretting this - he is not saying 'there is something other than genes at work' he is saying that 'genes and their products interact'. There isn't a gene or selection of genes that organise the others, pretty much all of them work together to make up the control system.
 
 The 'Earth is so suited to life' is also not a vaid argument, firstly becuase there looks to be hundred of places where life could exist, several in this solar system alone based off organisms requirements in the most extreme conditions on earth. Secondly the whole argument there is like saying 'how amazing - this mould looks exactly like the thing that has come out of it, it must have been made to hold it' rather than realising that it is life that is so suited to Earth. All you really need at the bare minimum is hydrocarbons and a polar solvent and they are found almost everywhere.
 
 

 Michael John Denton "An Anti-Darwin Intellectual Journey", in Dembski, W. A. (ed) "Uncommon Dissent: Intellectuals who Find Darwinism Unconvincing", p172.
 
 Denton gives examples of the folds in RNA which happen consistently, and independently of genetic coding... but these rules governing the folds... "These laws of protein form are strictly equivalent to the rules that govern the way atoms are combined into molecules or subatomic particles are combined into atoms to generate the periodic table of elements...
 
 The folds present stunning evidence, perhaps the first clear evidence discovered in biology, that highly complex organic forms can be generated by natural law. With the folds, the impossible has become possible - the basic building blocks of nature are specified in abstract laws of form and are not simply a mechanical program in the genes. They are lawful, emergent, self-organising forms and not contingent 'cleverly contrived machines'. Here is a set of forms that arise directly out of the basic properties of matter, confirming the inference I had previously drawn from reading Henderson, that life might be encoded in the basic properties of matter."
 
 Ibid, pp173-74
 

 Isn't this arguing against your point? Everyone already knows the laws of protein folding (its just getting the exact amount of each effect that is very hard to model). Other than coding for their structure, genes have nothing to do with protein folding - pure protein can be denatured and then if the dentauring agent is removed will reform back into the active form. Its all to do with attractions between different polarities of the residues of the amino acids and whether they are hydrophobic or hydrophilic alongside what conformations are actually possible. Not really the same at all as the rules that govern atoms combining to make moelcules - not sure what he is getting at here. 'Intelligence as an emergant property of carbon' is an fairly old idea, its not so much some kind of mystical "life might be encoded in the basic properties of matter" as the forms and molecules required will arise naturally wihtout any need for intervention.

 Well I distance myself from the God_is_real steam-roller
 
The gene-centric theory is already being questioned. Further, the earth seems so suited for life, it can't have been by chance that life came about by chance. The inference is that there's an intelligence/blueprint behind it. This does not mean that the Christian God is proved by it, or God in any definition. BUT it is a form of evolutionary theory that tackles the problems of the holes in Darwin's mechanistic models.
 Michael Denton agrees with when he states that the gene-centric theory of neo-Darwinism - is insufficient to explain all aspects of biology. He states “Yet by the late 1980s it was becoming obvious to most genetic researchers, including myself, since my own main research interest in the '80s and '90s was human genetics, that the heroic effort to find the information specifying life's order in the genes had failed. There was no longer the slightest justification for believing that there exists anything in the genome remotely resembling a program capable of specifying in detail all the complex order of the phenotype... From being 'isolated directors' of a one-way game of life, genes are now considered to be interactive players in a dynamic two-way dance of almost unfathomable complexity, as described by Keller in “The Century of the Gene”.
 
 
You are misinterpreting this - he is not saying 'there is something other than genes at work' he is saying that 'genes and their products interact'. There isn't a gene or selection of genes that organise the others, pretty much all of them work together to make up the control system.

 If you are talking about Michael Denton, then I am not misrepresenting what he said. He said the way certain parts of us form, is not reliant on genes. The pattern comes from without the genes (see below re: folds in RNA). Darwinism is all about the changes coming from within the genes.
 
The 'Earth is so suited to life' is also not a valid argument, firstly because there looks to be hundred of places where life could exist, several in this solar system alone based off organisms requirements in the most extreme conditions on earth.

 This just backs up the argument. You claim that there could be other places where life exists, but there isn't life there, therefore they are not suited for life, the earth is... it is so suited for life.
 
Secondly the whole argument there is like saying 'how amazing - this mould looks exactly like the thing that has come out of it, it must have been made to hold it' rather than realising that it is life that is so suited to Earth. All you really need at the bare minimum is hydrocarbons and a polar solvent and they are found almost everywhere.

 There is much more to this theory than that; including the position of the earth in relation to the sun, it's tilt, the fact we've got a moon, and the position and size of other planets.
 For the first factors, they all go to creating seasons, tides, change, life. The second, the other planets, they help protect the earth by, in a sense, acting like giant sweepers, drawing many would-be dangerous objects into their path, and not ours.

(ed) “Uncommon Dissent: Intellectuals who Find Darwinism Unconvincing”, p172.Denton gives examples of the folds in RNA which happen consistently, and independently of genetic coding... but these rules governing the folds... “These laws of protein form are strictly equivalent to the rules that govern the way atoms are combined into molecules or subatomic particles are combined into atoms to generate the periodic table of elements...
 The folds present stunning evidence, perhaps the first clear evidence discovered in biology, that highly complex organic forms can be generated by natural law. With the folds, the impossible has become possible - the basic building blocks of nature are specified in abstract laws of form and are not simply a mechanical program in the genes. They are lawful, emergent, self-organising forms and not contingent 'cleverly contrived machines'. Here is a set of forms that arise directly out of the basic properties of matter, confirming the inference I had previously drawn from reading Henderson, that life might be encoded in the basic properties of matter.”
 Ibid, pp173-74

 
Isn't this arguing against your point? Everyone already knows the laws of protein folding (its just getting the exact amount of each effect that is very hard to model). Other than coding for their structure, genes have nothing to do with protein folding - pure protein can be denatured and then if the dentauring agent is removed will reform back into the active form. Its all to do with attractions between different polarities of the residues of the amino acids and whether they are hydrophobic or hydrophilic alongside what conformations are actually possible. Not really the same at all as the rules that govern atoms combining to make molecules - not sure what he is getting at here. 'Intelligence as an emergent property of carbon' is an fairly old idea, its not so much some kind of mystical "life might be encoded in the basic properties of matter" as the forms and molecules required will arise naturally without any need for intervention.

 You hit the nail on the head when you said 'genes have nothing to do with protein folding', it is something that is patterned, and not determined by genes. How does neo-Darwin evolution - change in genes, account for it?
 They, Denton et al, argue for the suitability of Nature; a pattern within nature.
Tastyfish

If you are talking about Michael Denton, then I am not misrepresenting what he said. He said the way certain parts of us form, is not reliant on genes. The pattern comes from without the genes (see below re: folds in RNA). Darwinism is all about the changes coming from within the genes....
 
 You hit the nail on the head when you said 'genes have nothing to do with protein folding', it is something that is patterned, and not determined by genes. How does neo-Darwin evolution - change in genes, account for it?
 They, Denton et al, argue for the suitability of Nature; a pattern within nature.
 
 
 Again you are missing the point, think of it from the persepctive of designing a car - the intructions for building it do not require you to devise some means for combustion to occur, its a process that will happen naturally if the car is built like the instructions say. Same with the genes, the genes don't even code for half of the structures that make up our bodies but the machines that make them, in addition it has nothing in it that govern the rules for making these machines - just the parts that will work correctly when put together. Change in the genes results in a change in the amino acid sequence, due to the phsyical natures of amino acids this could alter the way the protein folds, which in turn may alter the final product.
 
 

 This just backs up the argument. You claim that there could be other places where life exists, but there isn't life there, therefore they are not suited for life, the earth is... it is so suited for life.
 
 There is much more to this theory than that; including the position of the earth in relation to the sun, it's tilt, the fact we've got a moon, and the position and size of other planets.
 For the first factors, they all go to creating seasons, tides, change, life. The second, the other planets, they help protect the earth by, in a sense, acting like giant sweepers, drawing many would-be dangerous objects into their path, and not ours.
 Advanced life, there is evidence that they may be life in most of the places that could support it (several asteroids even have the same IR spectrum as bacterial colonies, even some patchs of compounds that shouldn't survive in clouds on Venus that could be due to life, even more places we just haven't looked yet).
 Life can and probably has formed in a much greater variety of places than Earth, Earth is well suited to advanced life and seeing as the chance it would arise may actually be quite high - that it has done so and advanced is not suprising. These locations may be rare, but it would be more suprising to not find life on them than it is to find it. On a unviersal scale the chance of finding advanced life might be rare on any one planet, but on a planet that could support that type of life the chance is very high.
 Most of the rare factors only apply to the majority of earthlike life, and some of those are even to be expected (i.e large gas giants outside its orbit, rocky planets of the right elements within a certain band etc), not every time but if you have one, then you probably have more.
montalban

Again you are missing the point, think of it from the perspective of designing a car - the instructions for building it do not require you to devise some means for combustion to occur, its a process that will happen naturally if the car is built like the instructions say. Same with the genes, the genes don't even code for half of the structures that make up our bodies but the machines that make them, in addition it has nothing in it that govern the rules for making these machines - just the parts that will work correctly when put together. Change in the genes results in a change in the amino acid sequence, due to the physical natures of amino acids this could alter the way the protein folds, which in turn may alter the final product.

 Your analogy proves my point again. The design of how the things fit together is important. The actual function of them comes about later on. For the gene-centric argument you're arguing that the combustion system makes the car, not the other way around. The shape of the folds, so important to life (as the frame of the car is, to the placing of the engine), is not dependent upon the genes. So, you need to account for it. And the gene-centric arguments can't. And as with the design of the car, the actual positioning of all the components is important. ID theorists would welcome your contribution :)
 
Advanced life, there is evidence that they may be life in most of the places that could support it (several asteroids even have the same IR spectrum as bacterial colonies, even some patches of compounds that shouldn't survive in clouds on Venus that could be due to life, even more places we just haven't looked yet).

 Secondly, is bacteria 'advanced life'?
 
Life can and probably has formed in a much greater variety of places than Earth, Earth is well suited to advanced life and seeing as the chance it would arise may actually be quite high - that it has done so and advanced is not surprising.

 There is a difference between saying 'it is possible that life could exist', and 'life exists'. We know life exists on earth, not elsewhere. Therefore earth is suited for life.
 
These locations may be rare, but it would be more surprising to not find life on them than it is to find it. On a universal scale the chance of finding advanced life might be rare on any one planet, but on a planet that could support that type of life the chance is very high.

 If you are arguing for life in the galaxy based on statistics, show me your theory.
 
Most of the rare factors only apply to the majority of earthlike life, and some of those are even to be expected (i.e large gas giants outside its orbit, rocky planets of the right elements within a certain band etc), not every time but if you have one, then you probably have more.

Tastyfish

The only thing that is enabling the car to move and function as a car is the combustion reaction between the fuel and car, and this is something that was not designed by the engineer. However it is wrong to say that some other figure must have designed cars.
 
 The 'genecentric theory' (not actually a real term, it is known as the central dogma of molecular biology) does not state that genes encode every single piece of information that goes into building a human - instead it contains all the information needed to build a human. It means you use the right amino acids so that the protein will fold correctly.
 You are essentially arguing that 'isn't is mystical that Oxygen and Carbon can react to form Carbon Dioxide'. Genes don't need to code for natural laws, its the same as saying until Newton the laws of gravity did not apply. There is nothing at all mysterious or controversual in what he is saying. 
 
 The shape of the folds does depend on genes as it is they which detirmine the order of amino acids - no new information is being added at the protein folding stage, its just the amino acid residues that have been put in a chain interacting with each other.
 
 There is no evidence to show we have found other life, but there is evidence that shows there might be life there - either because we are seeing unsual elements and molecules that are hard to explain without life, or we are looking at habitats where we know earthlike life can exist and probably arose or very similar to them. It isn't easy however to spot bacteria with a satellite built in the 70s, newer probes are being built expressly for the purpose of checking these locations.
 
 Not sure what you mean by life based on statistics, its more the statistics of a suitable planet as far as advanced life goes - but if primative life can form on comets and other planets (we have martian rock on Earth thrown up from impacts on Mars) then it makes it likely that even if life doesn't arise on the more suited planets then it will get there eventually.
 
 Far as the stats go, it may be very unlikely to win the lottery, but are we suprised when someone does (even taking into account the need for suitability - i.e brought a ticket)
montalban

The only thing that is enabling the car to move and function as a car is the combustion reaction between the fuel and car, and this is something that was not designed by the engineer. However it is wrong to say that some other figure must have designed cars.

 That is totally false. If you had no means of traction such as wheels then you could have an engine as big as you want, and you're not going anywhere. The position of the engine to the wheels is equally important.
 A car needs an integrated system. It's not just an engine.
 It needs a fuel source, an ignition, connexion to the wheels, a means of regulating the power to the wheels, etc.
 
The 'genecentric theory' (not actually a real term, it is known as the central dogma of molecular biology) does not state that genes encode every single piece of information that goes into building a human - instead it contains all the information needed to build a human. It means you use the right amino acids so that the protein will fold correctly.

 So you're now saying that genes don't encode every single piece of information, but contain all the information needed to build a human, so where is the code coming from that produces the folds in RNA?
 You seem to be having two arguments at once.
 
 You are essentially arguing that 'isn't is mystical that Oxygen and Carbon can react to form Carbon Dioxide'. Genes don't need to code for natural laws, its the same as saying until Newton the laws of gravity did not apply. There is nothing at all mysterious or controversial in what he is saying. 

 I make no argument, not even close. I am saying isn't it interesting that the folds which are important for RNA to actual mean anything aren't controlled by genes. It's a difference between you and I talking about the words on the page you read in a book - which contain information, but you thinking its not important that the page is there to hold that information. Just the information itself is important. You need something to hold it, in place to give it meaning. The information is therefore not just the words, but how they are sorted, and how they are meaningful for us to use.
 Thus one editorial review of Denton reads
 
The shape of the folds does depend on genes as it is they which determine the order of amino acids - no new information is being added at the protein folding stage, its just the amino acid residues that have been put in a chain interacting with each other.

 Michael Denton seems to disagree with you on this.
 "From Publishers Weekly...
 New England biologist Denton continues the assault on Darwinian science, especially the theories of evolution and natural selection, that he began in Evolution: A Theory in Crisis. Here, Denton takes a page out of the work of 19th-century natural theologians like William Paley and 19th-century anti-Darwinian scientists like Robert Chambers to contend that, far from being random and without direction, the laws of nature operate by design. Moreover, says Denton, the design of the laws of the universe inevitably lead to one conclusion: "The entire process of biological evolution from the origin of life to the emergence of man was somehow directed from the beginning." Denton marshals a dizzying array of scientific evidence to bolster his conclusions. First, he examines the evidence from physics and chemistry for the inevitability that the development of a universe like ours would have the evolution of life as its goal. He discusses gravity, the nuclear energy levels of certain atoms, water, light, carbon, uranium and more as elements whose existence is perfectly orchestrated to usher human life onto the universe's stage. Denton then discusses evolutionary biology, arguing that the biocentric nature of the universe undermines the Darwinian principles of contingent natural selection. Denton's arguments are weakened by their circular nature (he assumes design in nature and proceeds to make pieces fit his argument whether they do so easily or not), but his prose is engaging and his insights are accessible to readers who lack a deep scientific background. In the growing debate over Darwin's theories, Denton's voice remains one of the most notable and compelling."
 You claimed I was misrepresenting what he said. Seems not.
 
There is no evidence to show we have found other life, but there is evidence that shows there might be life there 

 Again you make a nonsense statement. There is no evidence, but we do have evidence.
 
 either because we are seeing unusual elements and molecules that are hard to explain without life,

 Such as?
 
or we are looking at habitats where we know earthlike life can exist and probably arose or very similar to them

 Yes, that's statistics.
 Kent: Mr. Simpson, how do you respond to the charges that petty vandalism such as graffiti is down eighty percent, while heavy sack-beatings are up a shocking nine hundred percent?
 Homer: Aw, people can come up with statistics to prove anything, Kent. Forty percent of all people know that.
 It isn't easy however to spot bacteria with a satellite built in the 70s, newer probes are being built expressly for the purpose of checking these locations.
 
Not sure what you mean by life based on statistics, its more the statistics of a suitable planet as far as advanced life goes - but if primitive life can form on comets and other planets (we have Martian rock on Earth thrown up from impacts on Mars) then it makes it likely that even if life doesn't arise on the more suited planets then it will get there eventually.

 That's a statistical argument.... 'x' amount of planets, 'y' percent of them just must have life. Why? Well, they just must have.
 
Far as the stats go, it may be very unlikely to win the lottery, but are we surprised when someone does (even taking into account the need for suitability - i.e brought a ticket)

 Well there you go! More stats. What are the chances of there being life on other planets?
Tastyfish

That is totally false. If you had no means of traction such as wheels then you could have an engine as big as you want, and you're not going anywhere. The position of the engine to the wheels is equally important.
 A car needs an integrated system. It's not just an engine.
 It needs a fuel source, an ignition, connexion to the wheels, a means of regulating the power to the wheels, etc. 

 Fine consider that an example, however engineers didn't have to create friction, point still stands.
 
 

 So you're now saying that genes don't encode every single piece of information, but contain all the information needed to build a human, so where is the code coming from that produces the folds in RNA?
 You seem to be having two arguments at once.

 There is no code governing the mechanism of folds in RNA, the code that detirmines how the RNA folds is the the DNA. There is one argument, the atoms already have a set of behaviours that they follow naturally. Obviously the specific thing they do will depend on what residue is there, and that is coded for by DNA. If we are going more into it you need to deicde between RNA and protein - both have a similar thing but the system behind is different (RNA is a lot simpler, but mostly I have been talking about protein folding)
 
 

 I make no argument, not even close. I am saying isn't it interesting that the folds which are important for RNA to actual mean anything aren't controlled by genes. It's a difference between you and I talking about the words on the page you read in a book - which contain information, but you thinking its not important that the page is there to hold that information. Just the information itself is important. You need something to hold it, in place to give it meaning. The information is therefore not just the words, but how they are sorted, and how they are meaningful for us to use.
 The universe is capable of holding information and organsising it, or do you argue against the extistance of any natural law? 
 
 
 

 Thus one editorial review of Denton reads
 
 Michael Denton seems to disagree with you on this.
 "From Publishers Weekly...
 New England biologist Denton continues the assault on Darwinian science, especially the theories of evolution and natural selection, that he began in Evolution: A Theory in Crisis. Here, Denton takes a page out of the work of 19th-century natural theologians like William Paley and 19th-century anti-Darwinian scientists like Robert Chambers to contend that, far from being random and without direction, the laws of nature operate by design. Moreover, says Denton, the design of the laws of the universe inevitably lead to one conclusion: "The entire process of biological evolution from the origin of life to the emergence of man was somehow directed from the beginning." Denton marshals a dizzying array of scientific evidence to bolster his conclusions. First, he examines the evidence from physics and chemistry for the inevitability that the development of a universe like ours would have the evolution of life as its goal. He discusses gravity, the nuclear energy levels of certain atoms, water, light, carbon, uranium and more as elements whose existence is perfectly orchestrated to usher human life onto the universe's stage. Denton then discusses evolutionary biology, arguing that the biocentric nature of the universe undermines the Darwinian principles of contingent natural selection. Denton's arguments are weakened by their circular nature (he assumes design in nature and proceeds to make pieces fit his argument whether they do so easily or not), but his prose is engaging and his insights are accessible to readers who lack a deep scientific background. In the growing debate over Darwin's theories, Denton's voice remains one of the most notable and compelling."
 You claimed I was misrepresenting what he said. Seems not.
 Sorry, assumed he was a real biologist. No one is arguring that life didn't happen, so obviously the universe must have formed in such a way that life could arise - we can see it has. This is very different from saying that the Universe formed for life, real scientists treat this like an experiment (because fundamentally it is) and test hypothesis to see whether they would result in what we see today. There is no 'chance' that the Universe happened to be able to support life - it was inevitable because it has happened (course not all universes may be able to support life but that's an entirely different debate)
 
 

 Again you make a nonsense statement. There is no evidence, but we do have evidence.
 No direct evidence of any life found, but a vast array of circumstancial evidence that needs to be confirmed - two totally different things, just because life could form somewhere doesn't mean it has done, we might have missed a peice of the system. Again two completely different things.
 
 

 Such as?.
 
 
 

 Yes, that's statistics.
 Kent: Mr. Simpson, how do you respond to the charges that petty vandalism such as graffiti is down eighty percent, while heavy sack-beatings are up a shocking nine hundred percent?
 Homer: Aw, people can come up with statistics to prove anything, Kent. Forty percent of all people know that..
 Obviously seeing as some statistics can be made up then all must be wrong...great logic there
 
 

 That's a statistical argument.... 'x' amount of planets, 'y' percent of them just must have life. Why? Well, they just must have
 'Why' is covered under the chances of 'x' and 'y' happening - if earth like planets occur in 'x' amount of planets due to the way solar systems condense and from what materials and this occurs 'y' numbers of times due to the way that the early systems condense out. The it stands to reason that you would expect planets that are like Earth to be like Earth - course at the moment quite how 'like Earth' a planet must be we don't really know as we only have the one example of one. 
 
 

 Well there you go! More stats. What are the chances of there being life on other planets?
 No idea, no one knows due the vast range of different variables covering a broad range of fields along with some other things we may not have taken into account, or things we have assumed you need but are wrong. Just because we can't calculate the probability doesn't mean its impossible
